question: High open space, exposed structural elements. Obviously aimed at first time visitors to create feelings of... smallness, inadequacy.
answer: Good thing it ain't workin... Reed, what are we doing here? This guy's fast-food, strip-mall science --

question: This wasn't our first stop, in case you forgot NASA. And Victor's not that bad. He's just a little... Larger than life. He's financed some of the biggest breakthroughs of this century.
answer: You'd never know it. Jesus. That too?

question: Reed Richards and Ben Grimm to see --
answer: What's the price for a smile round here?

question: He knew about NASA. What if he made the call to shut us down --
answer: Ben, think about all the people we can help if this works --

question: Maybe you should think about yourself for once. You always let this guy push you round --
answer: We got what we wanted. That's enough.

question: You sure about this, Reed?
answer: Those solar winds are flaring, but I factored them into my coordinates and --

question: I was talking about us. Working together.
answer: Well, uh, based on our history...you can handle the biogenetics, and I'll focus on the molecular physics. Or, uhm, maybe I should take the biotech, you work the microscopes, since you have some background in electropho--

question: I'll schedule the launch. Call me in the morning to talk about resources and crew.
answer: I, uh, think I remember the number.

question: It's been changed.
answer: As far as crew, I was hoping Ben could pilot the mission --

question: Can't do it. I cannot do it.
answer: External SRBs, orbital system engines. Its just like the shuttles you flew in --

question: No. I cannot take orders from that underwear model. That wingnut washed out of NASA for sneaking two Victoria Secret wannabes into a flight simulator.
answer: Youthful high spirits.

question: They crashed it into a wall. A flight simulator.
answer: I'm sure he's matured since then. When have I asked you to do something you absolutely said you could not do?

question: Five times.
answer: I had it at four.

question: Guess some think faster than others. I hired Armani to design the pattern. These colors will look great on camera.
answer: They're ready for you, sir.

question: Showtime.
answer: Our numbers are through the roof. The IPO's tracking at fifty, sixty a share. The bank's five times oversubscribed --

question: It's not just the money. I could make money in my sleep.
answer: Then what is it?

question: History, Leonard. History. Everything else is conversation... How's the other matter?
answer: Harry Winston sends his regards.

question: Isn't that your speech?
answer: He's made a few changes.

question: This is your dream, Reed. You should be the one up there.
answer: Victor's better at these things.

question: I'll be watching over you.
answer: Just get back soon, or I start looking for a new groom.

question: Soon as I'm back, I'm gonna trade that in for a bigger rock.
answer: I don't care about rocks, I care about you. You bring him back in one piece, or you can forget being Best Man.

question: Please tell me your dawg's not trying to rekindle things with my sister.
answer: 'Course not. Strictly business.

question: Yeah, well, his eyes say different.
answer: Hey, two hearts got busted last time. Maybe she's not over it either.

question: Let's see
answer: Put your tiny little mind at ease.

question: You've been with me two years now.
answer: It's been a good two years, Victor... The company's accomplished so much.

question: Right, of course, the company... But you see, I've come to realize all the accomplishments in the world mean nothing without someone to share them with --
answer: Uh, Victor, I hope I haven't done something to make you think...

question: Sue, I've lived my life unafraid of taking big steps. And this is the biggest step yet. If it helps, think of this as a promotion. A merger of sorts... Four little words that can change our lives...
answer: The cloud is accelerating! I don't know what happened. We've got minutes until it hits, not hours...Victor, that storm's deadly -- the radiation's lethal. We need to abort.

question: Get a grip. Reed. We didn't come all this way to lose our nerve at the first little glitch. Just close the shields...
answer: Ben's still out there --

question: So reel him in. But we came here to do a job. So let's do it. Quickly.
answer: Ben, we need you back inside.

question: Ben, we need you back inside.
answer: I ain't done arranging your flowers, egghead.

question: Ben. This is serious. Turn around.
answer: Roger that, on my way.

question: It's too late for him, and soon it'll be too late for all of us.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Raising the shields.
answer: You can't leave them out there.

question: Watch me. Reed had his chance. You can't help them any more than I can.
answer: I can try.

question: Ben! Ben!
answer: Where...where am I?

question: Back on Earth. Victor's medical facility... We're in quarantine.
answer: Reed? ... Sue?

question: They're fine. Everybody else...is fine.
answer: What's wrong with me?

question: I swear to you they've done everything humanly possible. The best plastic surgeons in the world, Ben. You had the best --
answer: Give me a mirror...

question: They said that's not such a good idea, the shock alone could --
answer: Give me the god damn mirror!

question: How's she doing?
answer: Stable. Vitals are strong.

question: Blood panels show no irradiation. Good. You'll step up this protocol, every --
answer: Four hours. We know what we're doing... One more day of observation, then you're all cleared.

question: And where do we think we're going?
answer: I don't know if "we've" noticed, but the sickest runs this side of the Alps are right outside that window -- Finish the tests, I know -- could you give me a hand with this zipper? Not yet. Luckily grandma still sends care packages. Brubbles my Triddle Name.

question: You're hot!
answer: So are you!

question: I mean, you feel a little feverish.
answer: I've never felt better in my life. When do you get off work?

question: My shift ends at four, but I couldn't --
answer: Meet me at 4:01, top of the run. That'll give you a minute to freshen up.

question: How long was I out?
answer: Three days. I was worried about you. How are you feeling?

question: Solid. How you doing?
answer: I don't know. I just keep going over and over the numbers.

question: Reed. Even you can't compute every little thing.
answer: I should have done more, run more tests --

question: It was a freak of nature. Last I checked, you don't have a crystal ball. Let it go. You go through something like this, makes you appreciate having the right woman in your life.
answer: Yeah, you and Debbie and perfect --

question: Reed, I'm not talking about Debbie.
answer: What? Come on. She's got a good thing with Victor --

question: I'm sorry, did that cosmic-bath loosen your screws?
answer: He's smart, powerful, successful --

question: Well maybe you should date him.
answer: Ben. He'll give her the life she deserves. She ended up with the right guy. Things worked out for the best.

question: Me like-y.
answer: Stay right. Left is trouble.

question: I though we went over this.
answer: Last one down springs for room service. You're on fire!

question: Not this again --
answer: No

question: How's the IPO?
answer: Stable. We're looking at low twenties. It's a good number, considering the fallout from --

question: Reed's disaster. You know, I half- think he did this to me on purpose.
answer: Sir, I'm sure he wouldn't put himself --

question: Get me on the AM shows, Larry King, cover of the Journal... I've got to do something about this scar. Make sure they only shoot my right side.
answer: Actually, uh, people seem to think the scar "humanizes" you.

question: And that's a good thing?
answer: You know, maybe you should get some rest --

question: Later. First, I've got some unfinished business. A deal that needs closing...
answer: Sir, I've always wondered... Why Sue? You could have any woman in the world but --

question: Feeling better?
answer: Yes, thanks.

question: That's good. That's uh...good.
answer: You always had a way with words. I should be getting back.

question: I'm really happy for you and Victor.
answer: You're happy for me and Victor.

question: I can tell you guys are enjoying what was the best part of our relationship --
answer: Which was?

question: Passion. For science.
answer: You are such a dork, Reed... You never got it and never will unless it's explained to you in quantum physics.

question: What? What did I say?
answer: It's never what you say. It's what you don't say. What you don't do...

question: I...I...I just wanted to --
answer: It's been two years, and all you can say is you're happy for me and some other guy... You know, Victor may be a lot of things, but at least he's not afraid to fight for what he wants... And it's nice to be wanted sometimes. To be heard...seen... Reed, look at me.

question: Uh, Sue...? I can't.
answer: What? What do you mean you --

question: Hello, Operator? Deb... It's me. I need you to step out front.
answer: Out front? You home, baby? I got a surprise for you.

question: I got a surprise for you too.
answer: Ben?

question: Don't come any closer for a sec. This is gonna be kind of a shock... You remember when we said "together forever no matter what"?
answer: Baby, you're scaring me. Oh my G-g-g. What did you...do to Ben?

question: Deb, it's me. It's still me.
answer: Don't...don't...DON'T TOUCH ME!

question: Make sure you find Ben, bring him back here. And keep it quiet. I don't need this to hit the press.
answer: Yes sir. You've got the Mayor at eight, then a nine-thirty interview with the Journal --

question: Front page?
answer: Top left, like you asked. Today Wall Street. Tomorrow, who knows...maybe Washington.

question: What now? Reed...? What do we do? Ben's out there. Let's go get him.
answer: Look, we've got a friend out there in trouble. We need to get to him before --

question: What?
answer: We need to get past them. Sue. Your clothes. Lose them.

question: Well, Victor, the bank would like to congratulate you. On the fastest freefall since the Depression. We can't even give your stock away.
answer: Ned, you know I can turn this around.

question: You promised a cure-all, and came back with this. Who the hell's going to invest in a biotech company that turns its workers into circus freaks?
answer: I really appreciate all your support.

question: You've got a week, Victor. One week to turn this around. Or we pull out... This meeting is over.
answer: Goddamn book-keeper doesn't know preferred stock from livestock.

question: God, I've been so worried about you.
answer: Victor, your scar --

question: I told you, I'm fine. It's you I'm worried about.
answer: I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to --

question: Please, no apologies. I've arranged for your things to be moved to one of my condos. You'll have round-the clock care.
answer: Thank you, that's generous, but I think I should stay here. With my brother. Until we get a handle on this.

question: Sue. I think you should let my doctors have a look at you.
answer: Victor! What are you doing here?

question: I'm starting to wonder the same thing... How much do you know about what happened to you?
answer: Not much. We need to run tests to see the extent of the damage.

question: Well, let me know if there is anything I can do. We're all in this together now.
answer: Victor wait... I just wanted to say, I'm sorry the mission didn't go as planned --

question: Didn't go as planned? It was a catastrophe. You ruined the lives of four people --
answer: I ruined? With all due respect, I told you to abort --

question: Abort? Reed, I put my company, my name, billions of dollars on the line, and I will not let you make me look like a fool --
answer: Victor, if we could understand what happened to us --

question: Okay. I've uh, got some questions, from Sue. That she thought might be better coming from me... Can you, you know, go to the bathroom...like normal...
answer: Yeah. You don't wanna know the details.

question: Ben, I'm afraid I've got to ask --
answer: Not unless you want that clipboard stretched up your --

question: O-kay. We'll skip that question. Is there something about flames? About flaming, that you --
answer: What are you trying to say? Just because I dress well and like to dance --

question: What? No. I'm trying to figure out why we each ended up with different symptoms.
answer: Oh, well that's easy

question: It's not "invisibility" per se. You're bending the light around you with some kind of malleable force field. That's what you projected on the Bridge.
answer: What about you? You haven't eaten in days. How come you're never on this side of the microscope? Bruises...from the bridge?

question: Have you had any side-effects, from your powers?
answer: I've had some headaches. Migraines.

question: You should be able to bend light around other objects, even people, if you could control your emotional state better --
answer: Excuse me?

question: I'm saying, if you had a little more self control, you could locate the trigger. Can you remember the exact emotions when --
answer: Anger. Rage. Frustration.

question: Okay. Is there any way to duplicate that feeling? Some memory or...
answer: I'm sure I can come up with something.

question: How's that coming -- whoa --
answer: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I didn't mean to do that... You must think that was some kind of latent hostility or --

question: What in the world would give me that idea? I mean, you broke up with me, right?
answer: Are you kidding?

question: No, I distinctly remember
answer: Reed. I was ready for the next step, you weren't, ergo, I walked.

question: I think it was a little more complicated than --
answer: I just wanted to share an apartment. What was so complicated about that?

question: There were a lot of variables to consider --
answer: No. There weren't. There was you. And me. No variables, no math. It was actually the simplest thing in the world. But your head got in the way... like it always does.

question: Sue...I just...I thought...
answer: Same old Reed. Too much thinking...

question: So what's the prognosis?
answer: Your tissue, your organs, your entire biophysical structure is changing. Every system is still functioning, somehow --

question: And they're changing into...
answer: I don't really know. A compound organic-metallic alloy. Stronger than titanium or carbon steel. Harder than diamonds --

question: Like the shields Reed said would protect us. How long?
answer: At this rate, the infection should be complete in two, maybe three weeks --

question: What do you mean "complete"?
answer: I wish I could tell you. I can't pretend to know what we're dealing with here. I'll notify the CDC and --

question: What?
answer: The Center for Disease Control. If this thing is contagious --

question: Look at me. I have a life. I'm the face of a billion-dollar-company... We need to keep this confidential, understand?
answer: But...this disease...is progressive... degenerative...

question: Nothing...nothing...nothing... Of course...of course...the cloud...
answer: What are you doing?

question: The plants, from space. Their particles are still charged. With the right amount of energy, those ions could create the elemental profile of the cosmic storm. If we can build a machine to re-create the storm, we can reverse the polarity --
answer: And reverse the mutations --

question: Curing countless diseases, not just ours.
answer: But we're the focus, right Reed? Reed...?

question: Of course. Of course.
answer: And you sure you can control this thing? Last time didn't work out so well.

question: With the right energy, we can stabilize the storm. Maybe tie into the city grid...
answer: You really need to get a janitor. This must be what it looks like inside your head.

question: There's a system to it. Wait! Sue, don't touch tha--
answer: Sorry. My fault. I won't...touch anything.

question: That's not funny! Ernie. Sorry for killing your business. I'll take the usual, then I'm out... Better make it a double.
answer: Who killed the party?

question: If there's a God, she hates me.
answer: I don't think She's real big on hate.

question: You wouldn't say that, if you could see me.
answer: Can I...? See you...? It's okay, I won't bite... ...not that I could. Such a sad face... You know, sometimes being different isn't a bad thing.

question: Trust me, this ain't one of those times.
answer: See you round, Benny... I'm Alicia, by the way.

question: Thank you for coming out to see me.
answer: You said it was urgent.

question: It is. There's something we need to talk about. Something I need to ask you...
answer: Victor, wait, slow down a second. I want you to know I appreciate everything you've done for me, but I just don't --

question: Susan. What are you doing? You think I brought you here to talk about us? Please. This is business. I need to know
answer: He's working round the clock. But the data needs to be tested, analyzed before --

question: Same old Reed. All analysis, no action. Wasn't that the problem with you two?
answer: If these molecules aren't stable, they could make us worse, maybe even kill us.

question: Then why is Reed dragging his feet? Maybe he likes having his prize specimen under glass... It's ironic, isn't it? You're finally the perfect woman for him...because you're his science project.
answer: Please don't make this personal --

question: Oh, I think you already have.
answer: Victor, we can't do anything until the research is ready.

question: Ben! Slow down... He didn't mean it. You know Johnny. He's always been a hothead --
answer: It's not him. It's them. I can't live like this.

question: Just give Reed a little more time. You know how he works -- analyzing every little step before he takes one --
answer: It's easy for you to be patient.

question: No, it's not. I thought I was done waiting for Reed... We're all in this together now, Ben.
answer: Together? Look at me, Susie. You got no idea what I'd give...to be invisible. Your nightmare...is my dream.

question: This is how you "turn things around"? These freaks are on the front page and your company's in the obituaries.
answer: I have a plan to use their publicity for --

question: Victor, stop. The bank's lost enough already. This isn't a negotiation. It's a notification. We're pulling out.
answer: You need to look long-term here. Without risk, there's no --

question: Reward. We all know the sales pitch, Vic. And frankly, we're done buying... Gentlemen. Hello...? Von Doom? Gave me a little shock. No hard feelings, right? Nothing personal. You know, you could always move back to Latvura, start fresh. Maybe that's where you belong, back in the "old country."
answer: It's pronounced Latveria. This meeting's over, Ned.

question: Reed... He got what he wanted... Everything he wanted...he took from me. Now I'm going to take it back. Piece by bloody piece...
answer: Victor, are you...are you okay?

question: Don't worry about me. Worry about yourself.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: What I should have done a long time ago. Applications and patents, Reed. This all belongs to me.
answer: But I'm not done with the machine --

question: Which is precisely the point. Analysis is over. It's time for action. My men could have mass- produced this by now.
answer: Mass-produced? This isn't a toaster. You have no idea how it works.

question: Re-create the storm, invert the polarity here, reverse the mutation there. Don't talk to me like I'm some schoolboy. I've got the same Phd you do.
answer: The storm needs to be handled exactly right, or it could make our mutations worse, much worse, maybe even kill us... Victor, please. We need time to verify the data... We can't afford any mistakes -- there's only enough ions for two or three attempts.

question: Can I talk to you? Don't let Victor push you into making a mistake --
answer: He was going to take away all my data, equipment --

question: Better than your life. Victor's not the one who has to get into that thing. We are.
answer: Which is why I'm working twenty hours a day, checking every variable --

question: Every variable but yourself. You don't eat, sleep. You can't live in your head like --
answer: I'm not the only one in there. I got you, Vic, Ben, Johnny, all rattling around in there.

question: How'd you know it was me?
answer: I'm blind, not deaf. Wanna come in?

question: I'm not really dressed for a party.
answer: Relax, it's casual.

question: No, I mean...I'm a little...dusty... Those yours too?
answer: My step-dad's. I'm strictly into stone. I was wondering when you'd walk by.

question: My step-dad's. I'm strictly into stone. I was wondering when you'd walk by.
answer: You know, you could'a run an ad in the personals.

question: "Sensual blind chick seeks three-ton, rock-hard he-man for deep spiritual relationship."
answer: This ain't permanent. My friend Reed's working on a cure...I think.

question: Bennie. You feel pretty good as is.
answer: You don't know what it's like out there. Walking around like some kind of circus freak. People staring, whispering --

question: I wouldn't know anything about that.
answer: I mean...

question: Need a ride, Johnny? A few fans. Hope you don't mind.
answer: Gotta take care of the fans, right?

question: Look, I built my business knowing what people want. And right now, the people want you.
answer: And we don't want to let the people down now, do we?

question: No we don't. Which is why we need to strike while the iron's hot. I'm talking action figures, videogames, sponsors --
answer: Videogames? You serious? You talk to Reed and Sue about this?

question: I could get Ben to tap into the Baxter's main power to generate enough voltage --
answer: Reed. Shh. Just be quiet. And look up. Remember our first date here...? God, I was so nervous.

question: You were?
answer: Of course I was. I'd read all your papers on bioethics. Some of them two times just so I'd have something to say to you.

question: You know, I bribed the projectionist ten bucks to keep it open late?
answer: I gave him twenty. I didn't want that night to end.

question: Sue, you were right. It wasn't complicated. I just wasn't ready to be...to become... You can be a little intimidating. You always talked about how you liked the kind of man who could approach you...speak his mind. One who wasn't afraid to tell you what he wanted.
answer: I did. I did, Reed...but I wanted you to be that man. When I walked out, I waited ten minutes outside your door. Ten. Waiting for you to come find me.

question: Why didn't you say something?
answer: That would have kinda defeated the purpose. And Reed... I'm saying it now. Come find me. That's my nose, genius... These are my lips.

question: This seat taken?
answer: What are you doing here?

question: I'm worried about you.
answer: About me? How sweet.

question: Come on. Let me buy you something to eat. Looks like you could use the company.
answer: 'Scuse me.

question: I know it can't be easy. Life hasn't changed that much for Reed, Sue and Johnny. At least they can go out in public. But for you? People staring. Whispering behind your back...
answer: If you're trying to cheer me up you're doing a helluva job --

question: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love. To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.
answer: Reed's gonna fix me up --

question: For your sake I hope you're right. I'm sorry if that sounds a little skeptical.
answer: Skeptical...?

question: Yeah, I have that effect on people.
answer: Ben --

question: Oh, you remember my name do you? You happen to remember what you swore to do with every breath in your body?
answer: We're working as hard as we can --

question: Yeah. I can tell. Victor was right.
answer: Come on, this is nothing.

question: Glad "nothing" could take you away from your work.
answer: Ben, I don't know if this thing'll change us back or make us worse. I need you to be patient for a little while longe--

question: Look at me, Reed. Look at me!
answer: I am looking. That's why I can't make a mistake! I've got to get it right, and it's not right yet! We need to test this.

question: Johnny? Did you see Ben?
answer: Yeah, for the last time, I hope. I'm done with this freak show. I'm moving back to the real world.

question: Is that what you call it? "Real"?
answer: At least it beats living in a lab like somebody's science project.

question: Johnny, slow down. Think. You know mom didn't raise us to --
answer: Look around, sis! She's not here. So you can stop talking to me like I'm your little boy --

question: As soon as you stop acting like one. Come on, you're smarter than this. You think those people out there care about you? You're just a fad to them.
answer: Let's try something new

question: What do you want, Vic?
answer: To help you. I've run every test known to man. And they all yield the same result

question: Reed said it'd be weeks till --
answer: He also said we'd avoid that storm in space. And we know how that turned out. He couldn't generate enough power for the machine to reach critical mass. Yet another mistake for "Mr. Fantastic."

question: And you can? Power it up?
answer: Yes. I've found a new energy source. Tell me...do you want to be Ben Grimm again?

question: Let's do it. Oh my God... Th-thank you. THANK YOU...VIC?! Vic... What the...?
answer: Everyone thought I was safe behind those shields...

question: Victor, the machine worked for me. It can work for you --
answer: It did, Ben. It worked perfectly.

question: You planned this...?
answer: I've always wanted power. Now I've got an unlimited supply...

question: And no Thing to stand in your way.
answer: Take a good look, Ben. This is what a man looks like who embraces his destiny. One down, three to go. Right on cue.

question: Take a good look, Ben. This is what a man looks like who embraces his destiny. One down, three to go. Right on cue.
answer: Oh god Ben. Are you okay? You did it, you really did it...

question: No, Reed. I did.
answer: Victor...? What, what happened to you? What did you do to your --

question: Exactly what I said I would
answer: Victor, this isn't the way to --

question: Great. Heat-seeker.
answer: What are you doing --

question: Sis. Let me take care of you for once.
answer: But Johnny...you can't fly.

question: What has he done to you?
answer: How romantic.

question: Victor, please --
answer: It's Doctor Doom to you.

question: We know the machine works. It worked on Ben, it'll work on you. We can turn you back --
answer: Do you really think fate turned us into gods so we could refuse these gifts?

question: Victor. You always thought you were god.
answer: Sue please, let's not fight.

question: No, Victor... Let's.
answer: Susan...... You're fired. Marco... Polo. One more down. Now it's just the scientist and his specimen.

question: Sue, can I talk to you for a second? I found a broken gasket, from space --
answer: A gasket? Reed, we're at a party.

question: If one of us were to wear it...
answer: Reed. What are you doing?

question: No more thinking, no more variables... Sue Storm...will you... Sue? Sue? You there?
answer: Yes. That's my nose, genius... These are my lips.
